ILOTbet shares why elite clubs sack managers sooner than ever
When teams as powerful as Chelsea, Manchester United, and Real Madrid all decide, almost in unison, that their head coaches are no longer the answer, the easy explanation is results. But that explanation doesn’t survive even a cursory look.
When Enzo Maresca exited Chelsea, Ruben Amorim left Manchester United, and Xabi Alonso was removed at Real Madrid, the instinctive reaction was to blame results. But results, in all three cases, only tell part of the story, and perhaps not the most important part.
Modern elite clubs don’t just employ managers to win matches. They hire them to represent an idea. When that idea starts to feel misaligned, tactically, culturally, or emotionally, the clock accelerates.
None of the three coaches collapsed competitively. Their records were uneven, yes, but hardly disastrous. Historically, such returns would have bought time, patience and at least a full season. That era is over.
At the top end of the game, clubs are no longer asking, “Are we good enough?” They’re asking, “Do we look and feel like ourselves?” If the answer is no, the spreadsheet becomes secondary.
This is why the traditional logic, win games, keep your job, no longer holds. Today’s elite clubs are brands first and football teams second. Every match is content. Every performance is messaging. Every press conference is part of the product.
Maresca’s Chelsea didn’t implode. They progressed, but not in a way that satisfied everyone upstairs. Chelsea’s ownership model is built on youth accumulation, asset growth and resale value, wrapped in a promise of competitive relevance. The manager isn’t just a coach; he’s a partner in a business plan.
When internal relationships fray, with sporting directors, medical teams or ownership, results become irrelevant. You can finish fourth and still feel like a miscast lead actor in someone else’s movie.
At United, Amorim faced a different trap. His tactical ideas were bold, modern and intellectually coherent. But Manchester United is not a laboratory. It’s a museum, a theatre and a battleground, all at once.
More damaging than league position was the growing sense that his team didn’t feel like United. The club’s mythical “DNA” is vague, often overused, but powerful. When former players, pundits and fans struggle to emotionally recognise what they’re watching, pressure multiplies quickly.
Public comments questioning internal structure only sped up an ending that already felt inevitable.
Alonso’s case may be the clearest example of philosophical mismatch. Real Madrid thrives under managers who manage people before patterns. The club’s greatest modern successes, six UEFA Champions League in 12 years, have come with elite ego-handlers rather than rigid system-builders.
Alonso, shaped by tactical innovation and success elsewhere, tried to blend structure with freedom. The result pleased neither purists nor romantics. At Madrid, ambiguity is fatal. You are either empowering stars or getting out of their way, preferably both.
When performances lack narrative clarity, even winning can feel unsatisfying.
None of the replacements scream long-term revolution. That’s intentional. These appointments are pressure valves, not masterstrokes. They reset the emotional temperature, reduce noise and buy time.
If they overperform, great. If not, they leave quietly. In a hyper-financialised sport, flexibility is king.
The modern managerial job at elite clubs is no longer about survival through results alone. It’s about cultural chemistry, brand compatibility, internal diplomacy, and emotional resonance with fans. Fail two or three of those, and no league position will save you.
Football hasn’t become less ruthless. It has become more self-aware. The biggest clubs are selling belief, identity and optimism, and the moment a manager is perceived to threaten that, the exit door opens.
